description: From Latin refractārius (“obstinate”), from refractus, past participle of refringere (“to break up”). Originally refractary, refractarie, but reanalysed after other adjectives in -ory.

adjectives.description: refractory (comparative more refractory, superlative most refractory)

entries.meaning: Obstinate and unruly; strongly opposed to something.
examples: Synonyms: (inanimates) contrary, fractious; see also Thesaurus:obstinate
Many of the vague and refractory cases of neck and shoulder pain and of migraine may be due to cervical disc disease.

entries.meaning: (biology) Incapable of registering a reaction or stimulus.
examples: The production of a generator potential leaves a refractory state in the receptor membrane  […]

entries.meaning: A material or piece of material, such as a brick, that has a very high melting point.
